Each year, millions of bats are killed by wind turbines around the world, but just one small change can reduce the number of bat fatalities at wind farms by at least 40%. All it takes is increasing the minimum wind speed at which wind turbine blades start to spin, because bats tend to fly around in high numbers when it isn't very windy. Right now, most wind turbine blades start spinning at wind speeds of 6.71 mph. New research published by an international team of bat experts has shown that increasing that speed to 10.1 mph can significantly reduce bat collisions with wind turbine blades. A recent trial run of this curtailment method in Australia resulted in 54% fewer bat fatalities, but that's not all. It only led to a 0.16% reduction in energy output and a 0.09% reduction in revenue. That means wind farm operators can do the right thing for the planet without sacrificing profit or output and without having to invest in expensive technologies. Some wind farm operators in North America and Europe already use this curtailment method, but it's not as common elsewhere in the world. Australia, though, is in the process of revamping their guidelines for onshore wind farms, and it currently calls for shutting down turbines when wind speeds are low in order to protect both bats and birds. So just because there are known issues with climate solutions does not mean they are being ignored. In fact, it's quite the opposite. Researchers all over the world are working tirelessly to develop more equitable and sustainable climate solutions, and this study focused on reducing bat fatalities at wind farms is no exception.
